intro: Melandrium caspum, commonly known as the Caspian catchfly, is a flowering plant native to central Asia. It belongs to the family Caryophyllaceae and is characterized by its delicate, pinkish-white flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in dry, sandy soils and is often found in steppe and grassland habitats. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are erect and branching. Melandrium caspum is a short-lived perennial that plays a minor role in its ecosystem but is of interest to botanists and horticulturists.
